bad.work: Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing

title.reg: Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing

titlestmt.title: Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 20KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 92KB to 1100KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesMarch 2020
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s water color illustrations to the plays of William Shakespeare.
Although less extensive and well known than his illustrations of John Milton’s poems, Blake’s water colors based on Shakespeare’s plays constitute a significant group of designs. The earliest, dating from c. 1779, is probably one of Blake’s illustrations of English history but nonetheless evokes Shakespeare’s King Lear. The series of seven small ovals picturing characters from the plays also dates from Blake’s early years. The concentrated focus on just one or two figures filling most of the pictorial space may be Blake’s response to popular interest in miniature portraiture. The reason for his execution of this group is not known; like the English history designs, they may have been intended for eventual publication as engravings. The series of Shakespeare character portraits by John Hamilton Mortimer, published as engravings in the mid-1770s, may have influenced Blake’s similar project.
Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing is one of Blake’s largest water colors of the 1780s. Its size and quality suggest that it may have been intended for exhibition, like the water colors illustrating the life of Joseph displayed at the Royal Academy in 1785. The circle of dancers and Puck’s stance with arms raised echo similar motifs in George Romney’s Leveson-Gower Family, painted in 1776-77 and published as a mezzotint by John Raphael Smith in 1781.
Blake was clearly attracted to the vision of Queen Katherine in Henry VIII, act 4, scene 2, for he executed four versions beginning c. 1783-90 and concluding with the highly finished and complex water color of c. 1825-26. Blake’s water color of Queen Katherine’s dream dated 1809 is part of a series of six illustrations to Shakespeare’s plays commissioned by Joseph Thomas, the clergyman who had earlier employed Blake to illustrate Milton’s Comus and Paradise Lost. In a letter of 31 July 1801 to William Hayley, John Flaxman added a postscript to Blake, including the following: “he [Thomas] also desired you [Blake] will make two designs in bister or Indian Ink, from Shakespeare’s Troylus & Cressida, Coriolanus, either of the 3 plays of Henry 6.th Richard the 3.d or Henry the 8.th each design for one play for which he will give a Guinea each, the dimensions as follow the paper. an upright square of 12 Inches & half by 8 Inches, within this Space leaving a moderate margin, the principal figure not exceeding 6 Inches high” (Butlin 547). Blake’s designs (most now trimmed) roughly follow these size requirements, necessitated by Thomas’s desire to create an extra-illustrated copy of the 1632 second folio of Shakespeare’s plays, but Blake waited eight years before completing the commission, changed the medium from monochrome drawings to water colors, and illustrated only two plays, Richard III and Henry VIII, specified by Flaxman. Blake may have chosen the other passages for illustration, at some point convincing Thomas of their appropriateness.
Many of Blake’s Shakespeare designs show his predilection for scenes dealing with perceptions that extend beyond the world of the physical senses. The four versions of Queen Katherine’s dream epitomize this lifelong interest in imaginative and visionary experiences. A corollary is Blake’s attraction to representations of the arts, demonstrated by Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing and his portrayal of Pegasus, the classical embodiment of poetic inspiration, in As If an Angel Dropped Down from the Clouds among the designs for Thomas.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
Morris Eaves, Robert N. Essick, and Joseph Viscomi, editors
Joseph Fletcher, managing editor, Michael Fox, assistant editor
The William Blake Archive

objtitle.title: Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing

objdescid.compdate: c. 1785The date is based on stylistic considerations.

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; sold by Catherine Blake c. 1829 to Henry Francis Cary; sold Christie's, 13 March 1895, lot 16 (£3.10s. to the dealer Leggatt Bros.); Alfred A. de Pass; given by de Pass in 1910 to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

desc.objtitle: Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing, Object 1 (Butlin 161)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night in this design that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. Two figures with blonde hair stand beside the left margin. Facing right, the male figure at left has short curly hair, a beard, and a mustache. He wears a spiky crown and a long gown with additional drapery, probably a cloak, visible behind him. His left leg is bent and crossed over his right. His right arm is slightly bent and by his side. A staff and flower (perhaps a lily) are visible near his right hand, though it seems more likely that these are held by his female companion, whose left arm is wrapped around his body. This figure has long hair and wears a headband or perhaps a diadem(?) as well as a long gown. She faces forward but turns her head to look down and to the right as she leans against her male companion at left. Her right leg is visibly bent beneath her gown. This pair is Oberon, king of the Fairies, and Titania, queen of the fairies, who together lead the other fairies in song and dance at the end of the play. To the right of this pair, a male figure, nude from the waist up, faces forward and looks toward the pair at left with a smile. He has short brown hair and wears knee-length pants or breeches. Blue leaves decorate his hair and waist; he also wears a necklace or ribbon tied around his neck. With elbows bent, he raises both arms vertically and appears to hold small instruments around the ring fingers of each hand, possibly castanets or finger cymbals. His left palm faces forward while he touches his thumb to his other fingers with the other hand. Both legs are bent with the right extended forward, perhaps to suggest dancing. This figure is Puck, also known as Robin Goodfellow, who is a hobgoblin in Oberon's service. Puck acts as a wise yet mischievous character throughout the play, and he states the final lines of the play: "So good night unto you all./ Give me your hands, if we be friends,/ And Robin shall restore amends (Act 5, Scene 1, 453-5). On the right side of the scene, four figures (who may all be female?) dance and hold hands in a circle. These are likely the other fairies in the trains of Titania and Oberon. The leftmost figure in the group faces right and wears a gown as well as a decorative headdress that resembles butterfly wings. Her hair is either short or arranged in a bun. She leans forward but also twists her body to raise her left arm vertically, where she touches her companion with her left hand, and extend her bent right arm forward to hold the hand of her other companion at right. Her left leg is extended backward as she appears to move in a clockwise direction. The next figure clockwise to her right faces forward but looks left and back toward her companion. She also wears a long gown that includes a circular flourish of fabric behind her back. Red petal-like objects adorn her head as her long hair streams to the left. She raises both bent arms horizontally with palms facing upward to touch the hands of her companions on either side. Her right leg is extended to the left as she moves in a clockwise direction. The third dancer at far right is the least distinct, though she(?) also wears a gown and has leafy decorations in her short hair and perhaps also around her waist. This figure faces right but turns her head to look left; her mouth may be slightly open. Both arms are extended (though the majority of the left is not visible), and she holds the hand of her companion at left. Her left leg is extended backward. Immediately in front of this figure, a disconnected arm is visible emerging from the right margin of the design to hold the right hand of the final figure, which suggests the complete circle of dancers contains five rather than four figures. The fully visible fourth figure, however, faces left and leans forward with right leg bent and left leg extended backward. She(?) wears a knee-length skirt and, like the figure behind her, has leafy foliage decorating her short hair and extending down her back. She extends her right arm backward to hold the otherwise disembodied arm and her left forward to touch the first dancer at left. The nighttime landscape in which these figures stand includes grassy ground, overhead leaves and vines, and perhaps the trunks of trees upper right and left. There are stars in the sky. A shadowy circle appears on the ground below the dancers. This is probably Blake's imaginative version of a fairy ring.

component.illusobjdesc: Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. Two figures with blonde hair stand beside the left margin. Facing right, the male figure at left has short curly hair, a beard, and a mustache. He wears a spiky crown (suggesting he may be a king) and a long gown with additional drapery (probably a cloak) visible behind him. His left leg is bent and crossed over his right. His right arm is slightly bent and by his side. A staff and flower are visible near his right hand, though it seems more likely that these are held by his female companion, whose left arm is wrapped around his body. He appears to look toward the scene of dancing in front of him at right. This figure is Oberon, king of the Fairies, who with his wife Titania, queen of the fairies, lead the other fairies in song and dance at the end of the play.

Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. Two figures with blonde hair stand beside the left margin. The female figure at right has long hair and wears a headband or perhaps a diadem(?) as well as a long gown. She faces forward but turns her head to look down and to the right as she leans against and embraces her male companion at left. It is likely that she holds in her left hand the staff or scepter and flower that are visible near her companion's right hand. Her right leg is visibly bent beneath her gown. This figure is Titania, queen of the Fairies, who with her husband Oberon, king of the fairies, lead the other fairies in song and dance at the end of the play.

A staff or scepter and the blossom of a flower, possibly a lily, are visible near the right hand of the male figure standing at far left though these are likely held by his female companion who wraps her left arm around his body. The staff is topped with a flower, possibly a fleur-de-lis.

Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. Two figures with blonde hair stand beside the left margin. The third figure from the left, a male figure, nude from the waist up, faces forward and looks toward the pair at left with a smile. He has short brown hair and wears knee-length breeches. Blue flowers decorate his hair and waist; he also wears a necklace or ribbon tied around his neck with a loose knot. With elbows bent, he raises both arms vertically and appears to hold small musical instruments around the ring fingers of each hand, possibly castanets or finger cymbals. His left palm faces forward while he touches his thumb to his other fingers with the other hand. Both legs are bent with the right extended forward, perhaps to suggest dancing. This figure is Puck, also known as Robin Goodfellow, who is a hobgoblin in Oberon's service. Puck acts as a wise yet mischievous character throughout the play, and he states the final lines of the play: "So good night unto you all./ Give me your hands, if we be friends,/ And Robin shall restore amends (Act 5, Scene 1, 453-5).
Blue leaves and vines decorate the hair and waist of the third figure from the left.

The third figure from the left raises both arms vertically and appears to hold small musical instruments, possibly castanets or finger cymbals, around the ring fingers of each hand, which he likely plays.

Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. On the right side of the image, four figures (who may all be female?) dance and hold hands in a circle. These are likely the other fairies in the trains of Titania and Oberon. The leftmost figure in the group faces right and wears a gown as well as a decorative headdress that resembles butterfly wings. Her hair is either short or arranged in a bun. She leans forward but also twists her body to raise her left arm vertically, where she touches her companion with her left hand, and extend her bent right arm forward to hold the hand of her other companion at right. Her left leg is extended backward and her right is on tiptoe as she appears to move in a clockwise direction.

Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. On the right side of the image, four figures (who may all be female?) dance and hold hands in a circle. These are likely the other fairies in the trains of Titania and Oberon. The second figure in this circle clockwise to the right faces forward but looks left back toward her companion. She also wears a long gown that includes a circular flourish of fabric behind her back. Red petal-like objects adorn her head as her long hair streams to the left. She raises both bent arms horizontally with palms facing upward to touch the hands of her companions on either side. Her right leg is extended to the left and her left foot is on tiptoe as she moves in a clockwise direction.

Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. On the right side of the image, four figures (who may all be female?) dance and hold hands in a circle. These are likely the other fairies in the trains of Titania and Oberon. The third dancer at far right is the least distinct, though she(?) also wears a gown and has leafy decorations in her short hair and perhaps also around her waist. This figure faces right but turns her head to look left; her mouth may be slightly open. Both arms are extended (though the majority of the left is not visible), and she holds the hand of her companion at left. Her left leg is extended backward.

In the center of the right margin, a disconnected arm is visible and appears to hold the right hand of the fourth dancer in the foreground, which suggests the complete circle of dancing fairies contains five rather than four figures.

Seven figures stand or dance in a grassy landscape at night that represents the final scene in Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream. On the right side of the image, four figures (who may all be female?) dance and hold hands in a circle. These are likely the other fairies in the trains of Titania and Oberon. In the lower right corner of the scene, the fourth figure faces left and leans forward with right leg bent to stand on tiptoe and left leg extended backward. She(?) wears a knee-length skirt and, like the figure behind her, has leafy foliage decorating her short hair and extending down her back. She extends her right arm backward to hold the otherwise disembodied arm and her left forward to touch the first dancer at left.
Blue flowers, leaves, and vines decorate the hair and waists of the two rightmost dancers in the scene.

Seven figures stand or dance in a nighttime landscape that includes grassy ground, overhead leaves and vines, and perhaps the trunks of trees upper right and left. The large leaves upper left are probably ivy. Pen and ink lines lower left and above the head of the fairy with petal-like decorations in her hair suggest reeds.
A shadowy circle of light appears on the ground below the dancers. This is probably Blake's imaginative version of a fairy ring.
The dark coloring of the scene suggests the time is night. There are stars in the sky.
